wordpressPost.title: The Importance of Probiotics
wordpressPost.content:
The Importance of Probiotics

Inside of us live a vast amount of bacteria.  Without that bacteria we could not remain in good health.

Believe it or not, each of us has several billion!  Yep, several billion and they are divided into 400 species.

Most of the bacteria live in the intestinal tract.  Some of the bacteria keep our health on tract while the others allow us regain our health once the bacteria have been upset.

To help supplement the friendly bacteria, we could use a supplement known as a Probiotic.  A Probiotics meaning is “for life.” 

Lactobacillus acidophilus is the friendly bacteria in our upper intestinal tract.  It helps to reduce harmful bacteria, yeast and produces lactase which is an enzyme that we need for digestion.

Bifidobacterium bifidum and B. longum are the friendly bacteria in the large intestine and they do the same as the previous but also, help to produce B vitamins and help our body detoxify bile.

Without bacteria such as acidophilus we would not be able to properly digest our food and absorb vitamins and nutrients.  However, digestion is only a mere part of what probiotics can do.

Here is the list of some of the benefits of probiotics and friendly bacteria:

  • Manufacture B vitamins
  • Enhance our immune system
  • Create the lactase enzyme that is important for the digestion of dairy products
  • They kill hostile bacteria
  • May be active against tumors
  • Help with digestion
  • Reduce cholesterol levels
  • Protect against radiation damage
  • Deactivate toxic pollutants
  • Recycle estrogen and helps with menopausal symptoms

Friendly bacteria has been show to be useful in treatments for a number of ailments and diseases, specifically, cystitis, candidiasis, colitis, irritable bowel syndrome and some forms of cancer and ongoing infections.

When to use probiotic supplements: (Not all but some)

  • Chronic bowel problems
  • When traveling and used against food poisoning
  • After taking (and during) antibiotics
  • For premenopause and menopausal women
  • High cholesterol
  • Chronic acne, skin issues, allergies, arthritis, cancer (with professional guidance)
  • Undergoing radiation
  • For vaginal or bladder infections like cyctitis
  • Bifidobacteria infantis given to all babies (talk to your doctor)

To find a good probiotic, I go to places like Whole foods.  You will find them in the refrigerated section of your supplement isle.

If you can, get the powder and make sure it comes in a dark glass container and NOT PLASTIC!

You should take a probiotic with meals as our stomachs have extreme acids that can kill the bacteria without food.

Check the expiration date and use your probiotic up to that date and then replenish them.

A usual dose is about one billion and ten billion bacteria per day. You can increase this amount to 15-20 billion if you are taking antibiotics however, talk with your doctor as some probiotics can affect the metabolism of certain antibiotics.

Once you open your probiotics, keep the refrigerated because they are alive!
